reviewText:
I bought Agapan out of curiosity, since I thought the project was dead after a not-so-successful Indiegogo campaign. So here is a first impression review.

Description:
Agapan is an story-driven RPG Maker game with no fighting. The many, fully drawn characters and cutscenes remind of a Visual Novel.

Gameplay:
You explore the foggy town of Agapan, helped by a fast travel system. Talking to villagers and triggering events makes the story progress, day after day.

Story:
So far, so good. Less character development than in an actual VN, but the place is indeed mysterious and a few things definitely do not feel right.

Conclusion:
If you like slow paced, enigmatic games, and if you don't mind getting stuck with no clues from time to time, you may want to give Apagan a try.

reviewText: My luck with RPGMaker games has been incredible, I tell you. I keep buying these games and expect to encounter some cliché rpg or mediocre adventure, and pass some mindless time at best. Yet I always end up picking the ones with tremendous emotional and ethical depth. Agapan is the latest example of my extraordinary luck.\n\nLet's start with the meaning of this rather alien word: Agapan. Agapan means to be ready and alert

reviewText:
'Agapan' could be described as a spiritual follower of the unforgettable 'To the Moon' - it is an adventure game focused on story-telling and made with 'RPGmaker' engine - i.e., expect small characters on the screen we view from the above, with anime (or something) styled dialogues.

The story is quite nice - think of a Lovecraftian little town but with South-American flavor - and with many mysteries, of course.
As for the gameplay, we even get an inventory - but the puzzles are mostly based on wandering from one part of town to another. Still, there are multiple endings based on player choices!

So, it is a nice little game about 4 hours long - try it if you liked 'To the Moon'!

reviewText:
RPGMaker game that is story rich and the gameplay is only about exploring a town named Agapan".
There is a multiple ending for this game.
The story itself is full of mystery as It will only be revealed after you reach a certain ending. (Not all ending will reveal all the truth).

Player take control of David Garcia as he's trying to find his relative. He's been an orphan for 10 years.
One day
date: he found a chance to meet his grandmother in a town named "Agapan".\nThat's the starting point of exploring the foggy town."

reviewText: This isn't as much of a game as it is more of a play through story. There is no challenge or threat of death other than the story itself has. There are several diffrent endings depending on choices you make, I got four diffrent ones but it seems like there are more. At first there is a lot of walking to find the main areas where events take place and once you have found them all you can easly travel to each one. It may be hard to advance if you do not find all the events or items which are easy to miss. I was stuck on day two for a while because I was unable to notice an item on the floor near the clinic. Keep in mind this is just for the story and doesnt have any real gameplay value.

THIS is what right looks like, THIS is how you make a RPG maker game!

What we have here is a beautiful story told with text, cutscene art and music, the use of all these is clearly done by a dev that knows what he's doing.  THIS is the gold standard for RPG maker games on Steam, I want to see more like this.

Pros
Artstyle
Story is very good
Music is perfect for the mood/feel of the game

Cons
Like any great RPG I just wish it was longer lol.

reviewText: In this game you'll sometimes have to wander around and search for items without any clues. But the story is amazing. At first it's getting more and more mysterious but at the end you start to figure things out. It has multiple endings, so it makes it good for multiple runs. The soundtrack is awesome too.

I am really enjoying this game so far. It's a story driven style game and there's no fighting, which I really like. It's a nice break from the typical RPG's I usually play. I only got stuck once and looked for a walkthrough of this game or something. There are no walkthroughs for this game! O.O  There were a few video walkthroughs on youtube but they all only covered a small portion of the beginning of the game. Anyways, I finally figured out where I was supposed to go when I remembered that there's a small building on the back, right side of the church and after that it was smooth sailing.\n\nI'm not sure how many endings there are but the game description says 'over a dozen'. So far I've seen endings' C1, C2, D and F1. The only thing that could make this game better would be the addition of trading cards and most definitely some achievments. More specifically, ending related achievements to help you keep track of which endings you've unlocked and which ones you have yet to see. Other than that it's a great game. I highly recommend it.
